meta.name: Description

head.title: Combined Effects of Zeta-potential and Temperature of Nanopores on Diffusioosmotic Ion Transport | Analytical Chemistry

meta.content: Combined Effects of Zeta-potential and Temperature of Nanopores on Diffusioosmotic Ion Transport

Diffusioosmosis (DO) results from ion transport near charged surfaces in the presence of electrolyte gradients and is critical in nanofluidic systems. However, DO has not yet been comprehensively studied because nanofabrication materials have limitations of low throughput and difficult quantification. Herein, we describe a self-assembled particle membrane (SAPM)-integrated microfluidic platform that can modulate the material properties (e.g., zeta-potential) and transport flux of nanopores. We quantify the effect of the zeta-potential on DO by measuring the electrical signals across three different nanopores/nanochannels of the SAPM. We then empirically quantify the effects of the temperature and ionic strength of the electrolytes on DO and reveal a nonlinear relationship with DO-driven ion transport; the ionic strengths govern the DO- or diffusion-effective ion transport phenomena. Finally, we demonstrate DO-driven electric power generation with enhanced performance as a potential application under optimized experimental conditions.

div.span: Supporting Info (3)
SUBJECTS:

div.p: Diffusioosmosis (DO) results from ion transport near charged surfaces in the presence of electrolyte gradients and is critical in nanofluidic systems. However, DO has not yet been comprehensively studied because nanofabrication materials have limitations of low throughput and difficult quantification. Herein, we describe a self-assembled particle membrane (SAPM)-integrated microfluidic platform that can modulate the material properties (e.g., zeta-potential) and transport flux of nanopores. We quantify the effect of the zeta-potential on DO by measuring the electrical signals across three different nanopores/nanochannels of the SAPM. We then empirically quantify the effects of the temperature and ionic strength of the electrolytes on DO and reveal a nonlinear relationship with DO-driven ion transport; the ionic strengths govern the DO- or diffusion-effective ion transport phenomena. Finally, we demonstrate DO-driven electric power generation with enhanced performance as a potential application under optimized experimental conditions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Diffusioosmosis (DO) has attracted much attention in nanofluidic science
(1−3)
as a transport phenomenon universally occurring in nanopores and nanofluidic channels with surface charges under electrolyte gradients.
(4,5)
Typically, an electric double layer (EDL) features negligible DO at the microscale or in microfluidic channels (>2–50 μm);
(6)
however, DO becomes dominant at the nanoscale and cannot be neglected.
(7)
Additional investigations are needed to clarify the feasibility and practical implementation of DO-based nanofluidic systems, in which the relationships among the temperature, material properties, and ionic strength parameters in DO-driven ion transport are of significant interest.
(8,9)
Most previous studies on DO use conventional nanofabrication processes with limitations in the materials governing the zeta-potentials (ζ) of the channel surfaces, throughput, dimensions, and the number of nanopores/nanochannels.
(10,11)
This hindered DO investigation because the governing parameters could not be varied easily. Typically, electric signals are measured along a single nanochannel, which limits the quantification accuracy because of the low transport flux. Alternatively, bundles of nanochannels can be employed to enable the accurate quantification of DO (e.g., the quantification of the DO flux through nanoporous membranes) and the study of practical application feasibility. For instance, a carbon nanotube membrane was used for the quantitation of DO at different electrolyte concentrations to calibrate diffusioosmotic factors.
(12)
Additionally, nanoporous substrates (e.g., anodic aluminum oxide
(13)
and graphene oxide
(14)
membranes) were used to realize the light-driven active modulation of surface charge on nanochannels. Although such membranes allow one to manipulate DO-driven electric signals, the simultaneous variation of multiple parameters remains challenging. To date, the geometry and material properties of nanochannels and the surface charge and ionic strengths of electrolytes have been simultaneously varied. In addition, the out-of-plane direction of pores was shown to present a major spatial impediment to the integration of such membranes with heat sources and/or sinks for the manipulation of local temperature gradients. DO has been visualized using charged fluorescence dyes to estimate the velocity.
(15)
However, the estimated velocity can differ from that of ion transport; therefore, it is insufficient to analyze the DO characteristics of ion selectivity and ion flux.
(16)
Therefore, a versatile platform allowing the easy control of each parameter along with a mathematical approach is needed to clarify the unexpected theories in nanofluidic research. Moreover, parametric studies on DO are also strongly required to maximize the possibility of practical applications.
(17)

Here, a self-assembled particle membrane (SAPM)-integrated microfluidic platform was developed to empirically study and theoretically validate the DO transport through nanopores. The platform allows variations of the nanochannel ζ, electrolyte type, and electrolyte gradient, enabling convenient real-time observation. The fabrication of SAPMs with various nanoparticles has been reported previously.
(18,19)
Integration with a microfluidic channel network as the modulatory nanoporous membrane permits the SAPM-integrated microfluidic platform to function as a series of interconnected nanochannels with different material properties. This allows accurate characterization of the effect of the ζ on DO-driven ion transport by quantifying a highly amplified electric signal compared to that of a single nanochannel. Thereafter, the effects of temperature and ionic strength of the electrolytes on DO across the SAPMs are determined. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first experimental validation of DO; no prior attempts have been made to analyze the effect of electrolyte temperature on DO, although it is correlated to other DO parameters. Finally, the effect of multiple electrolyte mixtures on DO-driven ion transport is determined and an electric power generator is described as a potential application using optimized results.

A source meter (Keithley 2635A; Tektronix Korea Co., Ltd., Korea) and Ag/AgCl electrodes (541500; A-M Systems LLC) were used to measure the electric signals induced by ion transport. All SAPM-integrated microfluidic platforms and Ag/AgCl electrodes were subjected to sequential treatments with ethanol, distilled water, and electrolyte solutions. Then, the same potentiostatic method was used to measure the short-circuit current (SCC) and the open-circuit voltage (OCV). All measurements were conducted in a Faraday cage to suppress electrical noise.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure 1
describes the working principle of the SAPM-integrated microfluidic platform proposed in this study. In
Figure 1
a, the cationic counterions are transferred by DO, which is easily understood in a single nanochannel but creates a flux too weak to be measured accurately. By contrast, the DO flux inside multiple nanochannels is significantly amplified, enabling accurate and quantitative DO-driven ion transport measurement.
Figure 1
b shows the SAPM-integrated microfluidic platform comprising two main microchannels to load the electrolyte solutions. Between these, a SAPM is generated using another microfluidic channel to load the nanoparticles, which act as multiple nanochannels. The platform is fabricated using the microfabrication process in conjunction with the previously developed SAPM integration process (refer to
Supporting Information Methods and Figure S2
in the Supporting Information).
(18)
Three different nanoparticles (SiO
2
,
[email protected]
2
, and
[email protected]
2
) with similar average diameters of ∼140 nm but different material properties were used to produce SAPM devices with different ζ
p
values. Additionally, a TCD was placed below the device to locally control the temperature of the SAPM and thus the electrolyte temperature (see
Supporting Information Methods, Figure S3
, and
Movie S1
). Therefore, the proposed analysis platform enables the characterization of the combined effects of ζ and temperature on DO-driven ion transport.

div.p:

(b) Photograph and schematic of the SAPM-integrated microfluidic platform, where the SAPM formed between the two microfluidic channels (yellow and pink areas) acts as multiple nanochannels. The SAPM contains either SiO
2

[email protected]

[email protected]

Figure 2. Visualization and analysis of DO-driven ion transport through the SAPM. (a) Atto-633 red fluorescent dye (90 μM) for visualizing Na

div.div:
To further validate the experimental results, we performed numerical simulations (
Figure 2
d,e; see the
Supporting Information Simulation
) and compared the outcomes obtained in the presence (w/) and absence (w/o) of Atto-633 diffusion. Consistent with the results shown in
Figure 2
c, when diffusion is considered in the simulation, the concentrations on both sides plateau at ∼250 min, while these values continue to change when diffusion is not considered. This is because Atto-633 molecules migrate by DO, with no reverse transport by diffusion allowed.
Figure 2
e shows the concentration gradient of Atto-633 along the SAPM. When the diffusion of Atto-633 is allowed (w/
J
D_Atto-633
), the concentration of Atto-633 gradually increases along SAPM, i.e., from 34 μM at the left side to 113 μM at the right side. As a control, when the diffusion of Atto-633 is not allowed (w/o
J
D_Atto-633
), the concentration is nearly constant along the SAPM at 9 μM but dramatically increases up to 130 μM at the end of the SAPM (
Supporting Information Movie S2
). This theoretically confirms that DO-driven transport can be balanced by both diffusion-driven transport and ion-selective transport across the SAPM with time.

div.h3: Effects of Zeta-potential and Electrolyte Temperature
div.div:
Figure 3
shows the effects of the SAPM zeta-potential (ζ
SAPM
) and the electrolyte temperature on ion transport in the presence of the concentration gradients of NaCl and KAc, where
C
L
= 9 μM and
C
H
= 90 μM.
Figure 3
a illustrates the transport of anions (red circles) and cations (blue circles) governed by diffusion through the negatively charged nanochannel (gray). At the central region of the nanochannel, both the cations and anions diffuse through it by the concentration gradient (from
C
H
to
C
L
). Such transport phenomena continue until they reach an equilibrium. Because the surface of the nanochannel is negatively charged, cations are mostly present in the electric double layer (EDL; dashed line). At the same time, a convective flow known as DO (black arrows) is spontaneously generated inside the EDL. Because DO occurs in the region near the surface of the nanochannel (i.e., EDL), it transfers charged ions selectively, i.e., transfer of cations or anions
via
DO occurs near the negatively or positively charged nanochannel surface, respectively. DO occurs through the contribution of chemiosmosis (CO; purple arrows) and electroosmosis (EO; green arrows). The magnitude and direction of CO are governed by the concentration gradients of the electrolytes inside the asymmetric EDL along the nanochannel surface. Therefore, CO always occurs from a high- to low-concentration region. However, the magnitude and direction of EO vary based on the diffusivities (
D
) of the electrolytes. Each ion has a different
D
, where the diffusivity difference (β) is numerically expressed as follows
(22)
(1)
where
D
+
and
D
–
are the diffusivities of the cation and anion, respectively. In this study, electrolytes with different signs of β values were used; that is, β = −0.207 for NaCl and β = +0.285 for KAc. A positive β value implies that cations diffuse faster than anions and vice versa. Therefore, using electrolytes with opposite β values generates electric fields in opposite directions. As a result, the cation inside the EDL is transferred by the electric field such that the direction of EO depends on the β value of the electrolyte. Additionally, because the EDL thickness can be controlled by changing the mean concentration (
C
M
) of the electrolyte solution,
(23)
the resulting DO velocity profile can be subject to change. The Γ
DO
inside the EDL can be estimated using the following equation
(17)
(2)

are the dynamic viscosity of the fluid, Boltzmann’s constant, electrolyte temperature, ion valency, electron charge, ζ of the nanochannel surface (i.e., ζ of the nanoparticle (ζ
p
) in this study), and permeabilities of vacuum and water, respectively.

Although the ζ

eq 2

SAPM

DO-driven ion transport through SAPMs was analyzed by measuring SCC and OCV using the potentiostatic method (
Figure S6
).
(25,26)
Figure 3
c shows the SCCs obtained for three ζ
SAPM
for the same NaCl solution and three different temperatures (20, 50, and 80 °C). As the DO and diffusion directions are the same (from
C

to
C

Figure 3

| under these conditions. However, as temperature increases to 80 °C, the SCCs of SAPMs start to exhibit differences, as Γ
DO

SAPM
(

2
-based SAPM, which also had the highest absolute values of ζ = −87.3 mV and Γ
DO
= −2186.5 μm
2
/s. The OCV values were also measured and the transference number (
t
+
) was then calculated. In
Figure 3

C
H
to
C
L
) with cation selectivity (Na
+
in this case). As a result, the OCV of the SiO
2
-based SAPM with the highest
Γ
DO
exceeded those of the other SAPMs because of the higher cation transfer rate (i.e., Γ
DO
) of the former and could be enhanced by increasing the temperature (OCVs of 21.8, 24.8, and 27.8 mV are obtained at 20, 50, and 80 °C, respectively). In addition, the OCV and
t
+
values were also calculated in the absence of DO as a negative control result, by considering only the diffusion model over time with the same initial and boundary conditions (see
Supporting Information Simulation
). Hence, the experimental results are theoretically supported by numerical simulations. As β is independent of temperature (
Figure S7b
), the theoretical OCV remained constant with increasing temperature (
Figure S8
), whereas all experimental OCVs concomitantly increased. These differences demonstrate that DO-driven ion transport can be significantly effective at low electrolyte concentrations.
Figure 3
e shows that all SAPMs have cation selectivity (
t
+
> 0.5) because DO-driven ion transport carries more cations than anions. Conversely, the simulation result showed anion selectivity (
t
+
< 0.5) because of the negative β value in the absence of DO.

Figure 3

C
L
to
C

Γ
DO

Γ
DO
values of the SAPMs (
Figure S7c,d

Γ

[email protected]

in SiO

remained almost constant so that the number of cations transferred by DO through the SiO
2
-based SAPM was relatively less than that obtained at 50 °C. For the SiO
2

[email protected]

-based SAPMs, the
t
+

Figure 5. Synergistic DO-driven ion transport. (a) Diagrams of the four experimental conditions with NaCl and KAc concentrations of

div.div:
Figure 5
d shows the electric power generated for all experimental conditions to compare the potential applicability of the DO-driven ion transport. The power generated for both Cases I and II is similar at 20 °C for the SiO
2
-based SAPM and much higher than those in the other two cases, at 0.34, 0.28, 0.15, and 0.02 pW for Cases I–IV, respectively. This indicates that multispecies-based interdiffusion benefits power generation. For the
[email protected]
2
- and
[email protected]
2
-based SAPMs, less power is generated compared to that for the SiO
2
-based SAPM, similar to the SCC trend. These results indicate a synergistic effect of interdiffusion that increases SCC and OCV and thus yields the highest power generation. In addition, the power values depend on the SAPM materials because of their different Γ
DO
values. Although the use of mixed electrolytes increases power generation, the power values (<1 pW) remain insufficient for practical applications. As we reported previously,
(28)
an in-series array of SAPMs could be easily fabricated and integrated into the device to increase the throughput and the resulting electric power. Therefore, it is expected that the developed platform could be attractive in broadening the research scope of DO and enabling the improvement of the existing DO-based applications. The findings of this study are expected to facilitate the investigation of unexplored phenomena in fields related to electro- and chemo-kinetic ion transport at the nanoscale.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In sum, SAPM-integrated microfluidic platforms were developed and the combined effects of various parameters governing DO in the presence of electrolyte concentration gradients were determined. As the SAPM acts as interconnected and modulatory nanochannels, it facilitates the characterization of the effects of the nanopore zeta-potential, the electrolyte temperature, and ionic strength on DO. As a result, a nonlinear dependence of the measured electric signals was correlated with modulable parameters by comparison with the theoretical estimates of the DO mobility through nanochannels. The nonlinear effects of temperature and zeta-potential on the DO-driven ion transport along nanochannels were experimentally observed and measured. Furthermore, we identified the critical electrolyte concentration for achieving DO-driven versus diffusion-effective ion transport. Finally, the synergistic effect of an electrolyte mixture on the DO-driven ion transport was demonstrated by optimizing all experimental conditions to maximize power generation. We demonstrated that the SAPM-integrated microfluidic platform provides a novel approach for the simple, accurate, and comprehensive quantitative analysis of DO. These experimental results can be used for the development of DO-based applications. Importantly, these findings can facilitate the future exploration of more complex mass/ion transport phenomena at the nanoscale.

Microfluidic gradient generators are used to study the movement of living cells, lipid vesicles, and colloidal particles in response to spatial variations in their local chem. environment. Such gradient driven motions are often slow (less than 1μm s-1) and therefore influenced or disrupted by fluid flows accompanying the formation and maintenance of the applied gradient. Even when external flows are carefully eliminated, the solute gradient itself can drive fluid motions due to combinations of gravitational body forces and diffusioosmotic surface forces. Here, we develop a microfluid gradient generator based on the in situ formation of biopolymer membranes and quantify the fluid flows induced by steady solute gradients. The measured velocity profiles agree quant. with those predicted by anal. approxns. of relevant hydrodynamic models. We discuss how the speed of gradient-driven flows depends on system parameters such as the gradient magnitude, the fluid viscosity, the channel dimensions, and the solute type. These results are useful in identifying and mitigating undesired flows within microfluidic gradient systems.

McMullen Angus; Araujo George; Winter Michele; Stein Derek

A salinity gradient propels a DNA molecule through a solid-state nanopore and generates an ionic current whose change allows for the detection of the translocation. Measurements and theoretical analyses reveal the role of diffusio-osmosis in driving these phenomena: After accounting for known salinity-dependent electrode effects, the measured current change caused by the presence of a DNA molecule inside the nanopore and the DNA translocation speed through it both increase with the magnitude of the applied salinity gradients. The effects are consistent with the theory of diffuisio-osmosis and strong enough to enable DNA translocations to overcome an applied retarding potential of tens of millivolts. This work illustrates how salinity gradients can be used to power and operate a nanopore sensor.

Feldmann, David; Maduar, Salim R.; Santer, Mark; Lomadze, Nino; Vinogradova, Olga I.; Santer, Svetlana

The strong adhesion of sub-micron sized particles to surfaces is a nuisance, both for removing contaminating colloids from surfaces and for conscious manipulation of particles to create and test novel micro/nano-scale assemblies. The obvious idea of using detergents to ease these processes suffers from a lack of control: the action of any conventional surface-modifying agent is immediate and global. With photosensitive azobenzene contg. surfactants we overcome these limitations. Such photo-soaps contain optical switches (azobenzene mols.), which upon illumination with light of appropriate wavelength undergo reversible trans-cis photo-isomerization resulting in a subsequent change of the physico-chem. mol. properties. In this work we show that when a spatial gradient in the compn. of trans- and cis- isomers is created near a solid-liq. interface, a substantial hydrodynamic flow can be initiated, the spatial extent of which can be set, e.g., by the shape of a laser spot. We propose the concept of light induced diffusioosmosis driving the flow, which can remove, gather or pattern a particle assembly at a solid-liq. interface. In other words, in addn. to providing a soap we implement selectivity: particles are mobilized and moved at the time of illumination, and only across the illuminated area.

Diffusiophoresis (DP) is described as typically being divided into chemiphoresis (CP) and electrophoresis (EP), and the related theory is well-established. However, not only the individual effect of CP and EP but also the size dependency on the resulting DP of colloidal particles has not yet been comprehensively demonstrated in an exptl. manner. In this paper, we present a dynamic transport control mechanism for colloidal particles by developing a micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP). We demonstrate that the MNDP can generate transient and/or steady-state concn. gradients, making it possible to control the direction and rate of transport of colloidal particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP by simply and rapidly switching solns. In addn., the MNDP allows the size-dependent sepn. as well as fractionation of submicron particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP, thus empirically validating the classic theor. model for DP under the influence of elec. double layer (EDL) thickness. Furthermore, we provide theor. anal. and simulation results that will enable the development of a versatile sepn. and/or fractionation technique for various colloidal particles, including biosamples, according to their size or elec. feature.

Theory of diffusioosmosis in a charged nanochannel
Jing, Haoyuan; Das, Siddhartha
Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
(
2018
),

(

1463-9076

(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
We probe the diffusioosmotic transport in a charged nanofluidic channel in the presence of an applied tangential salt concn. gradient. Ionic salt gradient driven diffusioosmosis or ionic diffusioosmosis (IDO) is characterized by the generation of an induced tangential elec. field and a diffusioosmotic velocity (DOSV) that is a combination of an electroosmotic velocity (EOSV) triggered by this elec. field and a chemiosmotic velocity (COSV) triggered by an induced tangential pressure gradient. We explain that unlike the existing theories on IDO, it is more appropriate to apply the zero net current conditions (formulation F2) and not more restrictive zero net local flux conditions (formulation F1) particularly for the case where one considers a nanochannel connected to two reservoirs. We pinpoint limitations in the existing literature in correctly predicting the diffusioosmotic behavior even for the case where formulation F1 is used. We address these limitations and establish that (a) the induced elec. field is an interplay of the differences in ionic diffusivity, the EDL-induced imbalance in ion concns., and the advection effects, (b) formulation F1 may overpredict or underpredict the elec. field and the EOSV leading to an overprediction/underprediction of the DOSV and (c) formulation F2 demonstrates remarkable fluid physics of localized backflows owing to a dominant local influence of the COSV, which is missed by formulation F1. We anticipate that our theory will provide the first rigorous understanding of nanofluidic IDO with applications in multiple areas of low Reynolds no. transport such as biofluidics, microfluidic sepn., and colloidal transport.

The steady diffusioosmotic flow of an electrolyte soln. around a charged circular cylinder caused by a const. concn. gradient imposed in the direction along the axis of the cylinder is investigated theor. The cylinder can have either a const. surface potential or a const. surface charge d. of an arbitrary value. The elec. double layer surrounding the cylinder can have an arbitrary thickness, and its electrostatic potential distribution is detd. by an anal. approxn. to the soln. of the Poisson-Boltzmann equation. Solving a modified Navier-Stokes equation with the constraint of no net elec. current arising from the cocurrent diffusion, elec. migration, and diffusioosmotic convection of the electrolyte ions, the macroscopic elec. field and the fluid velocity along the axial direction induced by the imposed electrolyte concn. gradient are obtained semianalytically as functions of the radial position in a self-consistent manner. The direction of the diffusioosmotic flow relative to the concn. gradient is detd. by the combination of the zeta potential (or surface charge d.) of the cylinder, the properties of the electrolyte soln., and other relevant factors. For a prescribed concn. gradient of an electrolyte, the magnitude of the fluid velocity generally increases with increasing distance from the surface of the cylinder, but there are exceptions. The effects of the radial distribution of the induced macroscopic elec. field and of the ionic convection in the double layer on the diffusioosmotic flow are quite significant in practical situations.

Micro-/nanofabrication-based lab-on-a-chip (LOC) technologies have recently been substantially advanced and have become widely used in various inter-/multidisciplinary research fields, including biol., (bio-)chem., and biomedical fields. However, such hybrid-scale LOC devices are typically fabricated using microfabrication and nanofabrication processes in series, resulting in increased cost and time and low throughput issues. In this review, after briefly introducing the conventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies, we focus on unconventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies that allow us to produce either in situ micro-/nanoscale structures or master molds for addnl. replication processes to easily and conveniently create novel LOC devices with micro- or nanofluidic channel networks. In particular, microfabrication methods based on crack-assisted photolithog. and carbon-microelectromech. systems (C-MEMS) are described in detail because of their superior features from the viewpoint of the throughput, batch fabrication process, and mixed-scale channels/structures. In parallel with previously reported articles on conventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies, our review of unconventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies will provide a useful and practical fabrication guideline for future hybrid-scale LOC devices.

Osmosis plays a central role in many chem. sepn. processes. Among various biol. and artificial channels, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) stand out due to their exceptional water transport efficiency and variability of pore-size, down to mol. dimensions, thereby approaching ideal semipermeability. We report osmotically driven water and salt transport across a membrane of vertically aligned CNTs in a titania matrix whose surface is functionalized with a self-assembled monolayer of octadecylphosphonic acid. The increased steric hindrance and hydrophobicity at the pore entrance of CNTs improved salt rejection while maintaining enhanced osmotic water transport, thanks to an atomically smooth surface of the nanotubes. In addn. to the exptl. demonstration of osmosis, we obsd. a net neg. osmotic water flow at lower salt concn. gradient and non-Fickian behavior of the reverse salt flux. This observation is attributable to the interface-driven fluidic phenomenon known as diffusio-osmosis that drives water flow in the direction opposite to osmotic flow. The ion-CNT interactions are responsible for the simultaneous occurrence of the two osmotic transport mechanisms and the salt-specific osmotic transport characteristics.

Biol. light-driven ion pumps move ions against a concn. gradient to create a membrane potential, thus converting sunlight energy directly into an osmotic potential. Here, we describe an artificial light-driven ion pump system in which a carbon nitride nanotube membrane can drive ions thermodynamically uphill against an up to 5000-fold concn. gradient by illumination. Layered graphene oxide membranes (GOM) with densely packed sub-nanometer-wide lamellar channels show exceptional ionic and molecular transport properties. Mass and charge transport in existing materials follows their concentration gradient, whereas attaining anti-gradient transport, also called active transport, remains a great challenge. Here, we demonstrate a coupled photon-electron-ion transport phenomenon through the GOM. Upon asymmetric light illumination, cations are able to move thermodynamically uphill over a broad range of concentrations, at rates much faster than that via simple diffusion. We propose, as a plausible mechanism, that light irradiation reduces the local electric potential on the GOM following a carrier diffusion mechanism. When the illumination is applied to an off-center position, an electric potential difference is built that can drive the transport of ionic species. We further develop photonic ion switches, photonic ion diodes, and photonic ion transistors as the fundamental elements for active ion sieving and artificial photosynthesis on synthetic nanofluidic circuits.

The classical paradigm for osmotic transport has long related the induced-flow direction to the solute membrane interactions, with the low-to-high concn. flow a direct consequence of the solute rejection from the semipermeable membrane. In principle, the same was thought to occur for the newly demonstrated membrane-free osmotic transport named diffusio-osmosis. Using a recently proposed nanofluidic setup, the authors revisit this cornerstone of osmotic transport by studying the diffusio-osmotic flows generated at silica surfaces by either poly(ethylene)glycol polymers or ethanol mols. in aq. solns. Both neutral solutes yield osmotic flows in the usual low to high concn. direction, in contradiction with their propensity to adsorb on silica. Considering theor. and numerically the intricate nature of the osmotic response that combines mol.-scale surface interaction and near-wall dynamics, these findings are rationalized within a generalized framework. These elements constitute a step forward toward a finer understanding of osmotically driven flows, at the core of rapidly growing fields ranging from energy harvesting to active matter.

Osmosis across membranes is intrinsically assocd. with the concept of semipermeability. Here, however, we demonstrate that osmotic flow can be generated by solute gradients across nonselective, fully permeable nanochannels. Using a fluorescence imaging technique, we are able to measure the water flow rate inside single nanochannels to an unprecedented sensitivity of femtoliters per min flow rates. Our results indicate the onset of a convective liq. motion under salinity gradients, from the higher to lower electrolyte concn., which is attributed to diffusio-osmotic transport. To our knowledge, this is the first exptl. evidence and quant. investigation of this subtle interfacially driven transport, which need to be accounted for in nanoscale dynamics. Finally, diffusio-osmotic transport under a neutral polymer gradient is also demonstrated. The expts. highlight the entropic depletion of polymers that occurs at the nanochannel surface, resulting in convective flow in the opposite direction to that seen for electrolytes.

The accurate measurement of wall zeta potentials and solute-surface interaction length scales for electrolyte and non-electrolyte solutes, resp., is crit. to the design of many biomedical and microfluidic applications. We present a novel microfluidic approach using diffusioosmosis for measuring either the zeta potentials or the characteristic interaction length scales for surfaces exposed to, resp., electrolyte or non-electrolyte solutes. When flows contg. different solute concns. merge in a junction, local solute concn. gradients can drive diffusioosmotic flow due to electrokinetic, steric, and other interactions between the solute mols. and solid surfaces. We demonstrate a microfluidic system consisting of a long, narrow pore connecting two large side channels in which solute concn. gradients drive diffusioosmosis within the pore, resulting in predictable fluid velocity/pressure and solute profiles. Furthermore, we present anal. results and a methodol. to det. the zeta potential or interaction length scale for the pore surfaces based on the solute concns. in the main side channels, the flow rate in the pore, and the pressure drop across the pore. We apply this method to the exptl. data of Lee et al. to predict the zeta potentials of their system, and we use 3D numerical simulations to validate the theory and show that end effects caused by the junctions are negligible for a wide range of parameters. Because the dynamics in the proposed system are driven by diffusioosmosis, this technique does not suffer from certain disadvantages assocd. with the use of sensitive electronics in traditional zeta potential measurement approaches such as streaming potential, streaming current, or electroosmosis. To the best of our knowledge this is the first flow-based approach to characterize surface/solute interactions with non-electrolyte solutes.

Various microfluidic devices have overcome many disadvantages common to conventional bioreactor systems by enabling active manipulation of cell-culture conditions, monitoring of cellular responses in high-throughput mode, and extn. of target cells in a relatively rapid and low-cost manner. However, existing microfluidic devices still have limitations, including the complexity of their operation and a lack of availability of dynamic control of the chem. environment. Here, the authors present a novel microfluidic bioreactor array device capable of not only the stable and dynamic programming of cell-culture environments but also the selective extn. of target cells. This device comprises 64 microchambers in a 16 × 4 array format, and each microchamber is integrated with a robust and nanoporous membrane on one side and an H-shaped entrance on the other. The membrane made of self-assembled particles allowed continuous and sequential delivery of various nutrients contg. gene inducers to compartmentalized microbial cells, thereby enabling dynamic cell culturing. Addnl., the H-shaped entrance was used for local and selective blocking of the microchamber by employing UV-curable material, thereby enabling the retrieval of target cells from the device while sequestering nontarget cells in the microchambers. The results demonstrated that the targeted rare cells could be isolated and sepd. from a mixt. of cells by repeating the extn. procedure. Therefore, the authors anticipate that this microfluidic bioreactor array device will be widely used for not only screening/extn. but also off-chip postanalyses of various microorganisms.

The terminal velocity is calcd. of a nonconductive sphere through a slightly nonuniform soln. of a sym. charged, binary electrolyte. The anal. proceeds through an expansion in the small parameter λ (the ratio of the counterion-cloud thickness to the particle radius). Results to O(λ) are presented. The only property of the sphere's surface that affects the velocity is its zeta potential, ζ, when the electrolyte gradient vanishes; no information concerning the dependence of ζ upon ionic strength is needed. While the chemiphoretic effect always directs the particle toward higher electrolyte concn., the electrophoretic contribution can move the particle in either direction depending on the sign of βζ, where β is a normalized difference in mobilities between the cation and anion of the electrolyte; thus particle movement can be directed toward either higher or lower electrolyte concn. depending on the phys. properties. With slight algebraic rearrangement, the results are applicable to conventional electrophoresis (particle motion in an applied elec. field) and show excellent agreement with the numerical calcns. of R. W. O'Brien and L. R. White (1978).

A review. This paper summarizes theory, exptl. techniques, and the reported data pertaining to the zeta potential of silica and silicon with attention to use as microfluidic substrate materials, particularly for microchip chem. sepns. Dependence on cation concn., buffer and cation type, pH, cation valency, and temp. are discussed. The Debye-Hueckel limit, which is often correctly treated as a good approxn. for describing the ion concn. in the double layer, can lead to serious errors if it is extended to predict the dependence of zeta potential on the counterion concn. For indifferent univalent electrolytes (e.g., sodium and potassium), two simple scalings for the dependence of zeta potential on counterion concn. can be derived in high- and low-ζ limits of the nonlinear Poisson-Boltzmann equation soln. in the double layer. It is shown that for most situations relevant to microchip sepns., the high-ζ limit is most applicable, leading to the conclusion that the zeta potential on silica substrates is approx. proportional to the logarithm of the molar counterion concn. The ζ vs. pH dependence measurements from several expts. are compared by normalizing the ζ based on concn.

In an aq. soln., the surface of inorg. nanochannels acquires charges from ionization, ion adsorption, and ion dissoln. These surface charges draw counter-ions toward the surface and repel co-ions. In the presence of a concn. gradient, counter-ions are transported through nanochannels much more easily than co-ions, which results in a net charge migration of one type of ions. The Gibbs free energy of mixing, which forces ion diffusion, thus can be converted into elec. energy by using inorg. ion-selective nanochannels. Silica nanochannels with heights of 4, 26, and 80 nm were used in this study. We exptl. investigated the power generation from these nanochannels placed between two potassium chloride solns. with various combinations of concns. The power generation per unit channel vol. increases when the concn. gradient increases, and also increases as channel height decreases. The highest power d. measured was 7.7 W/m2. Our data also indicate that the energy conversion efficiency and the ion selectivity increase with a decrease of concns. and channel height. The best efficiency obtained was 31%. Power generation from concn. gradients in inorg. ion-selective nanochannels could be used in a variety of applications, including micro batteries and micro power generators.

Transport of colloids in dead-end channels is involved in widespread applications including drug delivery and underground oil and gas recovery. In such geometries, Brownian motion may be considered as the sole mechanism that enables transport of colloidal particles into or out of the channels, but it is, unfortunately, an extremely inefficient transport mechanism for microscale particles. Here, we explore the possibility of diffusiophoresis as a means to control the colloid transport in dead-end channels by introducing a solute gradient. We demonstrate that the transport of colloidal particles into the dead-end channels can be either enhanced or completely prevented via diffusiophoresis. In addn., we show that size-dependent diffusiophoretic transport of particles can be achieved by considering a finite Debye layer thickness effect, which is commonly ignored. A combination of diffusiophoresis and Brownian motion leads to a strong size-dependent focusing effect such that the larger particles tend to conc. more and reside deeper in the channel. Our findings have implications for all manners of controlled release processes, esp. for site-specific delivery systems where localized targeting of particles with minimal dispersion to the nontarget area is essential.

Although rapid advances have been made in micro/nano-scale devices, there is still a lack of clean and sustainable power source for them. Here we propose a high voltage nanofluidic energy generator inspired by elec. eel using ion-concn. gradients, which converts Gibbs free energy into electricity without any pollutants. The high voltage can be induced by alternatively multi-stacking cation and anion-exchange nanochannel network membranes (CE-NCNMs and AE-NCNMs) in a confined microscale space. These membranes were constructed by in situ self-assembled nanoparticles with hydroxyl and amine groups, resp. The multiple stacks of CE-NCNMs & AE-NCNMs were successfully realized by precisely guiding the nanodrops with the suspended pos. or neg. charged nanoparticles into the desired positions in the multilayered microchannel platform. The performance of the proposed nanofluidic energy generator was quant. investigated by changing nanoparticle species, intermembrane distance (IMD), and environmental temp. Interestingly, we found that our optimized IMD (∼80 μm) is very similar to the inter-cell membrane distance of electrocytes in natural elec. eels and the diffusion potential of a single full cell at this IMD (∼138 mV) is also similar to the net potential across a single electrocyte (∼150 mV). This optimized IMD is verified through not only elec. measurement but also by fluorescent tracing and numerical anal. using multiphysics simulation. The high voltage of up to 1 V achieved by stacking 20 full cells is, to the authors' knowledge, the highest value yet obtained by microfluidic systems harnessing ion-concn. gradients.

Microfluidic gradient generators are used to study the movement of living cells, lipid vesicles, and colloidal particles in response to spatial variations in their local chem. environment. Such gradient driven motions are often slow (less than 1μm s-1) and therefore influenced or disrupted by fluid flows accompanying the formation and maintenance of the applied gradient. Even when external flows are carefully eliminated, the solute gradient itself can drive fluid motions due to combinations of gravitational body forces and diffusioosmotic surface forces. Here, we develop a microfluid gradient generator based on the in situ formation of biopolymer membranes and quantify the fluid flows induced by steady solute gradients. The measured velocity profiles agree quant. with those predicted by anal. approxns. of relevant hydrodynamic models. We discuss how the speed of gradient-driven flows depends on system parameters such as the gradient magnitude, the fluid viscosity, the channel dimensions, and the solute type. These results are useful in identifying and mitigating undesired flows within microfluidic gradient systems.

A salinity gradient propels a DNA molecule through a solid-state nanopore and generates an ionic current whose change allows for the detection of the translocation. Measurements and theoretical analyses reveal the role of diffusio-osmosis in driving these phenomena: After accounting for known salinity-dependent electrode effects, the measured current change caused by the presence of a DNA molecule inside the nanopore and the DNA translocation speed through it both increase with the magnitude of the applied salinity gradients. The effects are consistent with the theory of diffuisio-osmosis and strong enough to enable DNA translocations to overcome an applied retarding potential of tens of millivolts. This work illustrates how salinity gradients can be used to power and operate a nanopore sensor.

The strong adhesion of sub-micron sized particles to surfaces is a nuisance, both for removing contaminating colloids from surfaces and for conscious manipulation of particles to create and test novel micro/nano-scale assemblies. The obvious idea of using detergents to ease these processes suffers from a lack of control: the action of any conventional surface-modifying agent is immediate and global. With photosensitive azobenzene contg. surfactants we overcome these limitations. Such photo-soaps contain optical switches (azobenzene mols.), which upon illumination with light of appropriate wavelength undergo reversible trans-cis photo-isomerization resulting in a subsequent change of the physico-chem. mol. properties. In this work we show that when a spatial gradient in the compn. of trans- and cis- isomers is created near a solid-liq. interface, a substantial hydrodynamic flow can be initiated, the spatial extent of which can be set, e.g., by the shape of a laser spot. We propose the concept of light induced diffusioosmosis driving the flow, which can remove, gather or pattern a particle assembly at a solid-liq. interface. In other words, in addn. to providing a soap we implement selectivity: particles are mobilized and moved at the time of illumination, and only across the illuminated area.

Diffusiophoresis (DP) is described as typically being divided into chemiphoresis (CP) and electrophoresis (EP), and the related theory is well-established. However, not only the individual effect of CP and EP but also the size dependency on the resulting DP of colloidal particles has not yet been comprehensively demonstrated in an exptl. manner. In this paper, we present a dynamic transport control mechanism for colloidal particles by developing a micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP). We demonstrate that the MNDP can generate transient and/or steady-state concn. gradients, making it possible to control the direction and rate of transport of colloidal particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP by simply and rapidly switching solns. In addn., the MNDP allows the size-dependent sepn. as well as fractionation of submicron particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP, thus empirically validating the classic theor. model for DP under the influence of elec. double layer (EDL) thickness. Furthermore, we provide theor. anal. and simulation results that will enable the development of a versatile sepn. and/or fractionation technique for various colloidal particles, including biosamples, according to their size or elec. feature.

We probe the diffusioosmotic transport in a charged nanofluidic channel in the presence of an applied tangential salt concn. gradient. Ionic salt gradient driven diffusioosmosis or ionic diffusioosmosis (IDO) is characterized by the generation of an induced tangential elec. field and a diffusioosmotic velocity (DOSV) that is a combination of an electroosmotic velocity (EOSV) triggered by this elec. field and a chemiosmotic velocity (COSV) triggered by an induced tangential pressure gradient. We explain that unlike the existing theories on IDO, it is more appropriate to apply the zero net current conditions (formulation F2) and not more restrictive zero net local flux conditions (formulation F1) particularly for the case where one considers a nanochannel connected to two reservoirs. We pinpoint limitations in the existing literature in correctly predicting the diffusioosmotic behavior even for the case where formulation F1 is used. We address these limitations and establish that (a) the induced elec. field is an interplay of the differences in ionic diffusivity, the EDL-induced imbalance in ion concns., and the advection effects, (b) formulation F1 may overpredict or underpredict the elec. field and the EOSV leading to an overprediction/underprediction of the DOSV and (c) formulation F2 demonstrates remarkable fluid physics of localized backflows owing to a dominant local influence of the COSV, which is missed by formulation F1. We anticipate that our theory will provide the first rigorous understanding of nanofluidic IDO with applications in multiple areas of low Reynolds no. transport such as biofluidics, microfluidic sepn., and colloidal transport.

The steady diffusioosmotic flow of an electrolyte soln. around a charged circular cylinder caused by a const. concn. gradient imposed in the direction along the axis of the cylinder is investigated theor. The cylinder can have either a const. surface potential or a const. surface charge d. of an arbitrary value. The elec. double layer surrounding the cylinder can have an arbitrary thickness, and its electrostatic potential distribution is detd. by an anal. approxn. to the soln. of the Poisson-Boltzmann equation. Solving a modified Navier-Stokes equation with the constraint of no net elec. current arising from the cocurrent diffusion, elec. migration, and diffusioosmotic convection of the electrolyte ions, the macroscopic elec. field and the fluid velocity along the axial direction induced by the imposed electrolyte concn. gradient are obtained semianalytically as functions of the radial position in a self-consistent manner. The direction of the diffusioosmotic flow relative to the concn. gradient is detd. by the combination of the zeta potential (or surface charge d.) of the cylinder, the properties of the electrolyte soln., and other relevant factors. For a prescribed concn. gradient of an electrolyte, the magnitude of the fluid velocity generally increases with increasing distance from the surface of the cylinder, but there are exceptions. The effects of the radial distribution of the induced macroscopic elec. field and of the ionic convection in the double layer on the diffusioosmotic flow are quite significant in practical situations.

Micro-/nanofabrication-based lab-on-a-chip (LOC) technologies have recently been substantially advanced and have become widely used in various inter-/multidisciplinary research fields, including biol., (bio-)chem., and biomedical fields. However, such hybrid-scale LOC devices are typically fabricated using microfabrication and nanofabrication processes in series, resulting in increased cost and time and low throughput issues. In this review, after briefly introducing the conventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies, we focus on unconventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies that allow us to produce either in situ micro-/nanoscale structures or master molds for addnl. replication processes to easily and conveniently create novel LOC devices with micro- or nanofluidic channel networks. In particular, microfabrication methods based on crack-assisted photolithog. and carbon-microelectromech. systems (C-MEMS) are described in detail because of their superior features from the viewpoint of the throughput, batch fabrication process, and mixed-scale channels/structures. In parallel with previously reported articles on conventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies, our review of unconventional micro-/nanofabrication technologies will provide a useful and practical fabrication guideline for future hybrid-scale LOC devices.

Nanofabrication is playing an ever increasing role in science and technol. on the nanometer scale and will soon allow the authors to build systems of the same complexity as found in nature. Conventional methods that emerged from microelectronics are now used for the fabrication of structures for integrated circuits, microelectro-mech. systems, microoptics and microanal. devices. Nonconventional or alternative approaches have changed the way the authors pattern very fine structures and have brought about a new appreciation of simple and low-cost techniques. The authors present an overview of some of these methods, paying particular attention to those which enable large scale prodn. of lithog. patterns. The authors preface the review with a brief primer on lithog. and pattern transfer concepts. After reviewing the various patterning techniques, the authors discuss some recent application issues in the fields of microelectronics, optoelectronics, magnetism as well as in biol. and biochem.

Osmosis plays a central role in many chem. sepn. processes. Among various biol. and artificial channels, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) stand out due to their exceptional water transport efficiency and variability of pore-size, down to mol. dimensions, thereby approaching ideal semipermeability. We report osmotically driven water and salt transport across a membrane of vertically aligned CNTs in a titania matrix whose surface is functionalized with a self-assembled monolayer of octadecylphosphonic acid. The increased steric hindrance and hydrophobicity at the pore entrance of CNTs improved salt rejection while maintaining enhanced osmotic water transport, thanks to an atomically smooth surface of the nanotubes. In addn. to the exptl. demonstration of osmosis, we obsd. a net neg. osmotic water flow at lower salt concn. gradient and non-Fickian behavior of the reverse salt flux. This observation is attributable to the interface-driven fluidic phenomenon known as diffusio-osmosis that drives water flow in the direction opposite to osmotic flow. The ion-CNT interactions are responsible for the simultaneous occurrence of the two osmotic transport mechanisms and the salt-specific osmotic transport characteristics.

Biol. light-driven ion pumps move ions against a concn. gradient to create a membrane potential, thus converting sunlight energy directly into an osmotic potential. Here, we describe an artificial light-driven ion pump system in which a carbon nitride nanotube membrane can drive ions thermodynamically uphill against an up to 5000-fold concn. gradient by illumination. The sepn. of electrons and holes in the membrane under illumination results in a transmembrane potential which is thought to be the foundation for the pumping phenomenon. When used for harvesting solar energy, a sustained open circuit voltage of 550 mV and a c.d. of 2.4μA/cm2 can reliably be generated, which can be further scaled up through series and parallel circuits of multiple membranes. The ion transport based photovoltaic system proposed here offers a roadmap for the development of devices by using simple, cheap, and stable polymeric carbon nitride.

Layered graphene oxide membranes (GOM) with densely packed sub-nanometer-wide lamellar channels show exceptional ionic and molecular transport properties. Mass and charge transport in existing materials follows their concentration gradient, whereas attaining anti-gradient transport, also called active transport, remains a great challenge. Here, we demonstrate a coupled photon-electron-ion transport phenomenon through the GOM. Upon asymmetric light illumination, cations are able to move thermodynamically uphill over a broad range of concentrations, at rates much faster than that via simple diffusion. We propose, as a plausible mechanism, that light irradiation reduces the local electric potential on the GOM following a carrier diffusion mechanism. When the illumination is applied to an off-center position, an electric potential difference is built that can drive the transport of ionic species. We further develop photonic ion switches, photonic ion diodes, and photonic ion transistors as the fundamental elements for active ion sieving and artificial photosynthesis on synthetic nanofluidic circuits.

The classical paradigm for osmotic transport has long related the induced-flow direction to the solute membrane interactions, with the low-to-high concn. flow a direct consequence of the solute rejection from the semipermeable membrane. In principle, the same was thought to occur for the newly demonstrated membrane-free osmotic transport named diffusio-osmosis. Using a recently proposed nanofluidic setup, the authors revisit this cornerstone of osmotic transport by studying the diffusio-osmotic flows generated at silica surfaces by either poly(ethylene)glycol polymers or ethanol mols. in aq. solns. Both neutral solutes yield osmotic flows in the usual low to high concn. direction, in contradiction with their propensity to adsorb on silica. Considering theor. and numerically the intricate nature of the osmotic response that combines mol.-scale surface interaction and near-wall dynamics, these findings are rationalized within a generalized framework. These elements constitute a step forward toward a finer understanding of osmotically driven flows, at the core of rapidly growing fields ranging from energy harvesting to active matter.

Osmosis across membranes is intrinsically assocd. with the concept of semipermeability. Here, however, we demonstrate that osmotic flow can be generated by solute gradients across nonselective, fully permeable nanochannels. Using a fluorescence imaging technique, we are able to measure the water flow rate inside single nanochannels to an unprecedented sensitivity of femtoliters per min flow rates. Our results indicate the onset of a convective liq. motion under salinity gradients, from the higher to lower electrolyte concn., which is attributed to diffusio-osmotic transport. To our knowledge, this is the first exptl. evidence and quant. investigation of this subtle interfacially driven transport, which need to be accounted for in nanoscale dynamics. Finally, diffusio-osmotic transport under a neutral polymer gradient is also demonstrated. The expts. highlight the entropic depletion of polymers that occurs at the nanochannel surface, resulting in convective flow in the opposite direction to that seen for electrolytes.

The accurate measurement of wall zeta potentials and solute-surface interaction length scales for electrolyte and non-electrolyte solutes, resp., is crit. to the design of many biomedical and microfluidic applications. We present a novel microfluidic approach using diffusioosmosis for measuring either the zeta potentials or the characteristic interaction length scales for surfaces exposed to, resp., electrolyte or non-electrolyte solutes. When flows contg. different solute concns. merge in a junction, local solute concn. gradients can drive diffusioosmotic flow due to electrokinetic, steric, and other interactions between the solute mols. and solid surfaces. We demonstrate a microfluidic system consisting of a long, narrow pore connecting two large side channels in which solute concn. gradients drive diffusioosmosis within the pore, resulting in predictable fluid velocity/pressure and solute profiles. Furthermore, we present anal. results and a methodol. to det. the zeta potential or interaction length scale for the pore surfaces based on the solute concns. in the main side channels, the flow rate in the pore, and the pressure drop across the pore. We apply this method to the exptl. data of Lee et al. to predict the zeta potentials of their system, and we use 3D numerical simulations to validate the theory and show that end effects caused by the junctions are negligible for a wide range of parameters. Because the dynamics in the proposed system are driven by diffusioosmosis, this technique does not suffer from certain disadvantages assocd. with the use of sensitive electronics in traditional zeta potential measurement approaches such as streaming potential, streaming current, or electroosmosis. To the best of our knowledge this is the first flow-based approach to characterize surface/solute interactions with non-electrolyte solutes.

Various microfluidic devices have overcome many disadvantages common to conventional bioreactor systems by enabling active manipulation of cell-culture conditions, monitoring of cellular responses in high-throughput mode, and extn. of target cells in a relatively rapid and low-cost manner. However, existing microfluidic devices still have limitations, including the complexity of their operation and a lack of availability of dynamic control of the chem. environment. Here, the authors present a novel microfluidic bioreactor array device capable of not only the stable and dynamic programming of cell-culture environments but also the selective extn. of target cells. This device comprises 64 microchambers in a 16 × 4 array format, and each microchamber is integrated with a robust and nanoporous membrane on one side and an H-shaped entrance on the other. The membrane made of self-assembled particles allowed continuous and sequential delivery of various nutrients contg. gene inducers to compartmentalized microbial cells, thereby enabling dynamic cell culturing. Addnl., the H-shaped entrance was used for local and selective blocking of the microchamber by employing UV-curable material, thereby enabling the retrieval of target cells from the device while sequestering nontarget cells in the microchambers. The results demonstrated that the targeted rare cells could be isolated and sepd. from a mixt. of cells by repeating the extn. procedure. Therefore, the authors anticipate that this microfluidic bioreactor array device will be widely used for not only screening/extn. but also off-chip postanalyses of various microorganisms.

The terminal velocity is calcd. of a nonconductive sphere through a slightly nonuniform soln. of a sym. charged, binary electrolyte. The anal. proceeds through an expansion in the small parameter λ (the ratio of the counterion-cloud thickness to the particle radius). Results to O(λ) are presented. The only property of the sphere's surface that affects the velocity is its zeta potential, ζ, when the electrolyte gradient vanishes; no information concerning the dependence of ζ upon ionic strength is needed. While the chemiphoretic effect always directs the particle toward higher electrolyte concn., the electrophoretic contribution can move the particle in either direction depending on the sign of βζ, where β is a normalized difference in mobilities between the cation and anion of the electrolyte; thus particle movement can be directed toward either higher or lower electrolyte concn. depending on the phys. properties. With slight algebraic rearrangement, the results are applicable to conventional electrophoresis (particle motion in an applied elec. field) and show excellent agreement with the numerical calcns. of R. W. O'Brien and L. R. White (1978).

A review. This paper summarizes theory, exptl. techniques, and the reported data pertaining to the zeta potential of silica and silicon with attention to use as microfluidic substrate materials, particularly for microchip chem. sepns. Dependence on cation concn., buffer and cation type, pH, cation valency, and temp. are discussed. The Debye-Hueckel limit, which is often correctly treated as a good approxn. for describing the ion concn. in the double layer, can lead to serious errors if it is extended to predict the dependence of zeta potential on the counterion concn. For indifferent univalent electrolytes (e.g., sodium and potassium), two simple scalings for the dependence of zeta potential on counterion concn. can be derived in high- and low-ζ limits of the nonlinear Poisson-Boltzmann equation soln. in the double layer. It is shown that for most situations relevant to microchip sepns., the high-ζ limit is most applicable, leading to the conclusion that the zeta potential on silica substrates is approx. proportional to the logarithm of the molar counterion concn. The ζ vs. pH dependence measurements from several expts. are compared by normalizing the ζ based on concn.

In an aq. soln., the surface of inorg. nanochannels acquires charges from ionization, ion adsorption, and ion dissoln. These surface charges draw counter-ions toward the surface and repel co-ions. In the presence of a concn. gradient, counter-ions are transported through nanochannels much more easily than co-ions, which results in a net charge migration of one type of ions. The Gibbs free energy of mixing, which forces ion diffusion, thus can be converted into elec. energy by using inorg. ion-selective nanochannels. Silica nanochannels with heights of 4, 26, and 80 nm were used in this study. We exptl. investigated the power generation from these nanochannels placed between two potassium chloride solns. with various combinations of concns. The power generation per unit channel vol. increases when the concn. gradient increases, and also increases as channel height decreases. The highest power d. measured was 7.7 W/m2. Our data also indicate that the energy conversion efficiency and the ion selectivity increase with a decrease of concns. and channel height. The best efficiency obtained was 31%. Power generation from concn. gradients in inorg. ion-selective nanochannels could be used in a variety of applications, including micro batteries and micro power generators.

High Current Ionic Diode Using Homogeneously Charged Asymmetric Nanochannel Network Membrane

A high current ionic diode is achieved using an asym. nanochannel network membrane (NCNM) constructed by soft lithog. and in situ self-assembly of nanoparticles with uniform surface charge. The asym. NCNM exhibits high rectified currents without losing a rectification ratio because of its ionic selectivity gradient and differentiated elec. conductance. Asym. ionic transport is analyzed with diode-like I-V curves and visualized via fluorescent dyes, which is closely correlated with ionic selectivity and ion distribution according to variation of NCNM geometries.

Size-dependent control of colloid transport via solute gradients in dead-end channels
Shin, Sangwoo; Um, Eujin; Sabass, Benedikt; Ault, Jesse T.; Rahimi, Mohammad; Warren, Patrick B.; Stone, Howard A.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
(
2016
),
113
(
2
),
257-261
CODEN:
PNASA6
; ISSN:
0027-8424
.
(
National Academy of Sciences
)
Transport of colloids in dead-end channels is involved in widespread applications including drug delivery and underground oil and gas recovery. In such geometries, Brownian motion may be considered as the sole mechanism that enables transport of colloidal particles into or out of the channels, but it is, unfortunately, an extremely inefficient transport mechanism for microscale particles. Here, we explore the possibility of diffusiophoresis as a means to control the colloid transport in dead-end channels by introducing a solute gradient. We demonstrate that the transport of colloidal particles into the dead-end channels can be either enhanced or completely prevented via diffusiophoresis. In addn., we show that size-dependent diffusiophoretic transport of particles can be achieved by considering a finite Debye layer thickness effect, which is commonly ignored. A combination of diffusiophoresis and Brownian motion leads to a strong size-dependent focusing effect such that the larger particles tend to conc. more and reside deeper in the channel. Our findings have implications for all manners of controlled release processes, esp. for site-specific delivery systems where localized targeting of particles with minimal dispersion to the nontarget area is essential.

High-voltage nanofluidic energy generator based on ion-concentration-gradients mimicking electric eels
Wang, Cong; Choi, Eunpyo; Park, Jungyul
Nano Energy
(
2018
),
43
(
),
291-299
CODEN:
NEANCA
; ISSN:
2211-2855
.
(
Elsevier Ltd.
)
Although rapid advances have been made in micro/nano-scale devices, there is still a lack of clean and sustainable power source for them. Here we propose a high voltage nanofluidic energy generator inspired by elec. eel using ion-concn. gradients, which converts Gibbs free energy into electricity without any pollutants. The high voltage can be induced by alternatively multi-stacking cation and anion-exchange nanochannel network membranes (CE-NCNMs and AE-NCNMs) in a confined microscale space. These membranes were constructed by in situ self-assembled nanoparticles with hydroxyl and amine groups, resp. The multiple stacks of CE-NCNMs & AE-NCNMs were successfully realized by precisely guiding the nanodrops with the suspended pos. or neg. charged nanoparticles into the desired positions in the multilayered microchannel platform. The performance of the proposed nanofluidic energy generator was quant. investigated by changing nanoparticle species, intermembrane distance (IMD), and environmental temp. Interestingly, we found that our optimized IMD (∼80 μm) is very similar to the inter-cell membrane distance of electrocytes in natural elec. eels and the diffusion potential of a single full cell at this IMD (∼138 mV) is also similar to the net potential across a single electrocyte (∼150 mV). This optimized IMD is verified through not only elec. measurement but also by fluorescent tracing and numerical anal. using multiphysics simulation. The high voltage of up to 1 V achieved by stacking 20 full cells is, to the authors' knowledge, the highest value yet obtained by microfluidic systems harnessing ion-concn. gradients.
